docs.lead_paragraph: A cancer pill licensed last week for its striking benefits against one kind of cancer also works exceedingly well against a different and incurable cancer, American and European scientists reported today at a cancer meeting here. The drug, Gleevec, received swift approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday for treating patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia, one of the four main types of the blood cancer.

headline.main: New Drug Fights Second Kind of Cancer

docs.abstract: American and European scientists report Gleevec, pill licensed for its striking benefits against chronic myelogenous leukemia, one of four main types of blood cancer, is producing equally striking benefits among patients with advanced cases of an intestinal cancer, gastrointestinal stromal tumor, which strikes at least 10,000 Americans each year; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A cancer pill licensed last week for its striking benefits against one kind of cancer also works exceedingly well against a different and incurable cancer, American and European scientists reported today at a cancer meeting here.    The drug,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many cancer patients receive chemotherapy at the end of life, even if their kind of cancer is known to be unresponsive to the drugs, according to a study reported here today. The study, involving cancer patients who died in Massachusetts in 1996, found that a third of them received chemotherapy in the last six months of their lives. That finding ''strongly suggests overuse of chemotherapy at the end of life,'' said Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel, the senior author.

headline.main: Study Suggests Overuse of Chemotherapy Near Life's End

docs.snippet: Many cancer patients receive chemotherapy at the end of life, even if their kind of cancer is known to be unresponsive to the drugs, according to a study reported here today.    The study, involving cancer patients who died in Massachusetts in 1996,...

docs.lead_paragraph: ROLAND CASH-MABRY coughs raspily into the translucent face mask that sends a medicinal mist into his airways, tightened by a severe asthma attack. The wheezing continues. After a few hours, he will leave Mount Sinai's pediatric emergency room and be assigned a hospital bed. The sufferer in the white T-shirt and black overalls is an old hand at this. He is checking in for his 14th hospital stay for asthma. But he still shakes his head in silent protest, perhaps at leaving his mother's side, for Roland is all of 2 years old.
docs.abstract: Article on rise in number of childen with asthma in East Harlem, which, with highest rate of asthma-related hospital visits for children of any New York neighborhood, has become magnet for research and control projects; scientists and doctors from hospitals, city agencies and universities are looking at effects of pollution, triggers like cockroaches and mice, genetic role and how people take medications; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 House Votes to Bar U.N. Dues Payment The House voted, 252 to 165, to withhold $244 million in dues to the United Nations next year unless the United States regained its seat on the Human Rights Commission. The Bush administration opposed the move, which is little more than symbolic unless the Senate follows suit. A8 'Fast Track' Trade Battle President Bush began a campaign to win Congressional support for broad authority to negotiate new trade agreements, sending an outline of his strategy to Capitol Hill. A9

docs.lead_paragraph: For three decades, the International Olympic Committee has been engaged in a game of chemical cat-and-mouse. Athletes use drugs to enhance their performances, scientists devise tests to identify those drugs, then the athletes move on to more sophisticated doping techniques. Now, the rules of the game may be changing, leaving the Olympic committee even further behind.

headline.main: PUSHING THE LIMITS -- A special report.; Someday Soon, Athletic Edge May Be From Altered Genes

docs.abstract: Special report, Pushing the Limits, on International Olympic Committee's concerns that athletes will soon employ genetic engineering to perform better; officials will discuss potential benefits and risks of genetic engineering and whether genetic manipulation should be banned entirely in sport; agency hopes to gather three dozen athletes, sports scientists, genetics experts, ethicists and policy officials from Food and Drug Administration and National Institutes of Health; concerns range from pragmatic to philosophical; photos; diagrams (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: First-quarter operating profit at Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. rose 15 percent as higher sales of women's health products and generic drugs outweighed the effect of rising costs. Profit from operations rose to $43 million, or 40 cents a share, from $37.2 million, or 37 cents, a year earlier, the company said. First-quarter results matched the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Revenue increased 67 percent, to $296.8 million, while operating expenses rose 56 percent, to $84.4 million.
docs.abstract: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc reports first-quarter operating profit rose 15 percent, to $43 million, up from year-earlier $37.2 million (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students simulate the effects of alcohol on their vision and motor skills. Then, after doing additional research on the dangers of driving while intoxicated, students create an educational activity that might convince a particular target audience not to use alcohol and/or drink and drive.
